name: Hotel Rialto Venezia

reviews.text: Is this the best hotel in Venice? I believe so; the staff went out of their way to make us feel comfortable in our new surroundings, the room was truly breath-taking from the glass chandalier to the fourposter bed and the morning breakfast was above standard.
reviews.title: Utterly Brilliant!

reviews.text: To add to this every morning me and my family were awoken by the view of the Rialto Bridge which as you can imagine was a once in a life time experience but the best thing for me, in terms of simple pleasures, that the hotel had to offer was the panoramic terrace; available to all visitors although few ever take the time to see, it has views all the way up and down the grand canal and admittedly my favourite part of my trip to venice was buying a italian wrap from the shop downstairs, taking it to the terrace and sitting in the sunshine all afternoon.
reviews.title: Best location and great staff make this the hotel to stay in Venice
Best Hotel In Venice
reviews.text: This is by far the best location to stay in Venice. It is so easy to get to when you arrive because it is just steps away from the Rialto Bridge boat ramp and with bags in tow you walk straight into the lobby. It is also easy when walking around Venice because there are many signs pointing in the direction of the Rialto Bridge so you can find your way back. It is in the heart of Venice and everything is within walking distance. There are ample resturants and shops next to the hotel. The rooms are nice and large for a european hotel and the staff could not have been nicer. I would recommend this to anyone staying for the first time in Venice because of the location and it's helpful staff. For me the hotel is what makes a trip and in this case I had a wonderful time and couldn't have been more pleased.

reviews.title: Would choose another location if staying in Venice again
reviews.text: Iam often travelling to Venice and stayed in many hotels, but the RIALTO HOTEL is by far my favourite choice... Great location (overlooking Rialto bridge), friendly and helpfull service, very good resturant and nice rooms. Great value for money... The quality is much better than the average 3* hotel. Definetely a recommendation for every traveller to Venice.

reviews.title: Simply Excellent
reviews.text: The Rialto Hotel was not only in an excellent position it was of great standard for a 3 star hotel. We actually checked into Al Graspo De Ua for the first two nights in Venice (booked by our travel agent) and found it was terrible (see our review!) When we decided to extend our Venice stay for another two nights we went to see the Rialto and found that it was cheaper and in a better position and the staff were very helpful and it had a lift!

Breakfast was the usual - we found it better to drink coffee out in Italy, but it was adequete for what we needed. St Marco Square, Rialto Bridge, the railway station and heaps of shops were in walking distance and we were able to spend our days wandering around the local area and returning to our hotel room when we needed to put away the shopping or put our feet up!
reviews.title: Terriffic Location

reviews.text: We were offered a free tour to Murano Island during as part of our stay at the Rialto which meant that a canal taxi took us out to the Island and we were shown the glass blowing factory and shown the beautiful original glass pieces (one of a kind and more expensive then what you find in the souvenir shops in Venice). The stuff was beautiful and you get a 50% discount off the marked price, we were unable to purchase any because we would have had to get it back to Australia, however would have loved to! Be warned though that the tour ends in the souvenir shop of the factory and you have to find your own way back to the hotel (we weren't told this). And whilst its only a cheap ferry ride back to Venice we wondered whether we would have been treated differently if we had purchased items from the exhibition?
reviews.title: Great Place to Stay
Position, position, position
reviews.text: Stayed in the Rialto for a long week-end break in mid Nov 05. Booked a room overlooking the Grand Canal/ Rialto Bridge. Wonderful location and base for sightseeing, eating out and people watching! Hotel accomodaion seemed to exceed the three star official rating with everything being "just so". Room size was more than adequate and exceptionally clean. Windows double glazed with excellent effect of keeping the very early canal workers outside and allowing us to sleep in peace. Wardrobe/hanging/drawer space were ample and, again, spotless! Staff very polite and accomodating and check out quick and easy. Breakfast room was small but run very efficiently. Nothing special about the breakfast but quality was good, as was quantity. Would recommend this hotel to anyone staying in this wonderful City. Go for it!
This hotel is like something out of a disney film with lots of gold and rococco styling. The hotel staff were a gem (despite the fact we rolled up on our first day at 0100 due to travel problems).
reviews.title: Gorgeous kitsch hotel!!
Tip top
reviews.text: I lost my passport and luggage on the way to venice and the staff could not have been more helpful and understanding.

reviews.title: Excellent Location, Service
reviews.text: The location is fabulous and the room service breakfast was plentiful.

reviews.title: nice but noisy
reviews.text: This Hotel is perfecly located for a trip to Venice.
The staff are very friendly and the rooms are lovely.
reviews.title: Excellent Hotel

reviews.text: My friends and I stayed here during the first weekend of Carnival. It was an excellent choice and well worth the price we paid for a junior suite with a canal view. The water bus stops just in front of the hotel and makes all of Venice accessible all day and night long. The suite was large enough for four women and their luggage, so no complaints regarding the size of the room. However, the bathroom was on the small side. The decor is typical Venetian and you really feel like you are getting a real taste of Italy. We weren't bothered by the foot or boat traffic along the Grand Canal. Breakfast was included but we never made it down in time. Having the Rialto markets right outside was very convenient for picking up last minute souvenirs. I would not recommend the hotel restaurant. The service was poor and the food wasn't very good. However, right next door there is a little place with great panini sandwiches. The location made it the perfect place for experiencing Carnival.
reviews.title: Worth the price...
Great hotel & location
reviews.text: This was as central as you can get, right by the Rialto bridge and with the vaporetto stop outside. Some might think it a little noisy, if in a Grand canal facing room, due to all the restaurants below and along the canal but we thought it all a part of the bustle & experience of being in the heart of Venice. Prices were reasonable compared to the Riva Schiavoni & St Marks Sq area. The famous Rialto markets are right opposite, just across the bridge and St Mark's Sq a 10 minute stroll through the lovely winding Venetian streets & alleys. The staff at the Rialto were multi-lingual & very friendly & helpful on the whole. Continental breakfast was buffet style with a very wide choice & hot breakfast items available for a small suppplement. We'd definitely want to stay here again when we do back to Venice. Take earplugs if you're worried about noise and want to have the Grand Canal view.

We had a junior suite which was very spacious and comfortable and immaculately clean. Do let them know if it's a special occasion, in our room there was a bottle of Prosecco and 2 glasses in a cooler on our arrival as it was our anniversary. A huge benefit of the Rialto Hotel is how easy it is to find - right by the 1 & 82 vaporetto stops so you don't have to spend any time hunting through the back streets with your luggage in tow - remember you can't take a car to your hotel so this was an important point. All traffic stops at the Piazzale Roma and you're on a boat from there so we were relieved to be in a hotel whose location made the journey so easy. We booked through Citalia but you can book direct with the hotel by using their website (-)rialtohotel(-)
reviews.title: Just superb !

reviews.text: Some basics about the geography. Venice City is an island (or rather a series of islands) set out about a mile or so from the Mainland in a sea water lagoon. It is connected to the Italian mainland by a causeway which carries a railway line and a roadway. Both the railway terminus and the end of road transportation is at the end of the causeway at Piazzale Roma (Rome Square). Venice's airport - Marco Polo Airport - is on the mainland about 10 miles away from Venice City, (although some budget airlines - like Ryanair fly to Treviso Airport, about twice that distance away). If you fly into Marco Polo the choice of transport to Venice City is either by private water taxi (90 Euros per boat one way); or a combination of bus or taxi to Rome Square/ Piazzale Roma (the closest place that road vehicles get to Venice City) and then transferring to a Vapporetti water bus (5 Euros per person) from there along the Grande Canal to the Rialto Vaportti stop - right outside the hotel. We pre-booked a taxi transfer with ATS (airport transfer services) which was 30 Euros to Rome Square and got the Vaporetti afterwards. Total transfer time about 1 hour. There's also an hourly express water bus from the Airport to St Marks Square (15 Euros each) - but you'll still need to get the Vaporetti from St Marks Square to the hotel at an extra 5 Euros each. The top tip really is to get the more expensive but "door-to-door" private water taxi from the airport and save all the fuss. Now the Rialto Hotel -what a great hotel! We stayed at the Rialto late last month, during Carnevale week in Venice. This was our first visit to the city and the carnival atmosphere certainly added to the experience. Carnevale is the week or so leading up to lent each year. The hotel is a charming 3 storey pink building, about 150 years old, set among similar buildings, right on the Grande Canal, about 10 metres from the Rialto Bridge. The reception is only a few steps away from the Vaporetti (water bus) stop at Rialto and is nicely appointed. Reception staff wear gold-trimmed, crimson velvet tunics, white ruff collars and are multi-lingual. Dining-room staff and the bell staff are similarly attired in 'period' uniforms. Our room (131) was along a maze of pristine pink marbled corridors. The door to our room had gilded panels - an ornate theme echoed on the cream-painted Italian wooden bedroom furniture within. Beautiful pink pavilion-striped padded fabric wall coverings, matching water-marked silk bed-covers and canopy. Lovely Venetian glass mirror and chandelier. Shutters on the double-glazed windows. Immaculate house-keeping and efficient individual climate controls in each room. Breakfast was included in the tarrif we booked on-line (through GTA hotels) and comprised the usual hot and cold continental buffet, with fruit, croissants, ham, salami, cheeses, cereals, yoghurts, juices, coffee, eggs etc. The hotel is in the centre of everything with some beautiful restaurants nearby - ranging from expensive fish restaurants (like the Cafe Grande Canal across the bridge - two course dinner, with lobster was 200 Euros for 2 persons)to great little Trattorias (like the Aquilla Nera) up an alleyway from the Campo San Bortolomio Square behind the hotel where dinner was around 40 Euros. St Marks Square is clearly signposted and a 10 minute walk through the cobbled streets. The Campenile Bell Tower, Basilica Church and Doge's Palace are all there along with pigeons galore - to feed for 1 Euro a bag. Admissions to the Campanile, Doge's Palace and Basillica are extremely reasonable - between 6 to 15 Euros for adults. The hotel has great souvenir shops and stalls all around, selling local cheeses, silk ties, glass, carnival masks to sports shops and more keychains and fridge magnets than most other tourist traps. Gondolas go from outside the hotel - but haggle with the Gondolier - a 40 minute trip should be no more than 100 Euros - expensive - but a MUST DO in Venice for the first time. This is an excellent, 4 star hotel, with furnishings which exude the ambience of Venice. Well situated, clean and stylish - the ideal choice for the tourist visiting the sites of this wonderful city. We travelled with our 10 year old son who loved the city. All the restaurants - even the fanciest - will happily rustle up things not on the menu such as a margherita pizza or french fries for fussy little eaters and feeding the birds in St Marks Square always pleases kids. A great city for romantics, photographers, shopaholics, families and those who love art, architecture and history. Something for everyone !

reviews.title: What a gem!

description: Located right in the centre, overlooking the Grand Canal and the Rialto Bridge. Picture yourself sitting at your junior suite window gazing out at the Rialto Bridge, probably the most famous landmark in Venice. Below, a steady stream of gondolas and boats make their way along the Grand Canal and the water-buses stop a few paces away so that the whole of Venice is at your disposal.
